questions.text: Tongue fasciculations are seen in
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Tongue fasciculations are a hallmark sign of a Lower Motor Neuron (LMN) lesion, which involves the degeneration of motor neurons in the spinal cord or brainstem.

  • Spinal Muscular Atrophy (SMA) is a motor neuron disease caused by the loss of LMNs (specifically the anterior horn cells) in the spinal cord and brainstem.

  • The Hypoglossal nerve (Cranial Nerve XII), which controls the tongue muscles, originates in the brainstem and is a Lower Motor Neuron.

  • The death of these motor neurons leads to muscle denervation, causing the muscle fibers to spontaneously twitch (fasciculations) and eventually waste away (atrophy).

  • In infants with severe SMA (Type 1), profuse tongue fasciculations are a characteristic and prominent clinical finding, often seen along with widespread muscle weakness and atrophy.

questions.text: You see a 1-year-old female whose problems began in infancy. Initially, she developed hypotonia. Now she has progressed to the point where she has severe weakness. She has hyporeflexia on examination and muscle fasciculations are noted—particularly of her tongue. She has not had any seizures or fever. Which of the following would not be of any use in treatment of previous case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

This patient shows a classic presentation of Spinal Muscular Atrophy (SMA): infantile-onset hypotonia, progressive weakness, hyporeflexia, and tongue fasciculations. SMA is a genetic disorder caused by mutations in the SMN1 gene, leading to degeneration of anterior horn cells (lower motor neurons).

  • Steroids (Option A) are not effective in SMA. They are mainly used in Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD) to reduce inflammation and slow muscle degeneration, but SMA is a neurogenic disorder, not an inflammatory or dystrophic myopathy. Hence, steroids have no therapeutic benefit in SMA.

questions.text: 34 year old woman was brought to the AIIMS Emergency after road traffic accident with GCS-3. She was intubated and NCCT was advised and was found to be normal with no space occupying lesion. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) DAI Diffuse axonal injury (DAI), also known as traumatic axonal injury (TAI), is a severe form of traumatic brain injury due to shearing forces. It is a potentially difficult diagnosis to make on imaging alone, especially on CT as the finding can be subtle, however, it has the potential to result in severe neurological impairment. The diagnosis is best made on MRI where it is characterized by several small regions of susceptibility artifact at the grey-white matter junction, in the corpus callosum, and in more severe cases in the brainstem, surrounded by FLAIR hyperintensity.

questions.text: What is the least useful investigation the diagnosis in the patient with following barium image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The provided barium swallow image shows the classic radiological signs of Achalasia:

  1. Dilated Esophagus (Mega-esophagus): The entire esophagus is significantly widened due to chronic food and fluid retention.

  2. Bird's Beak Appearance: There is a smooth, tapered, and fixed narrowing of the distal esophagus at the esophagogastric junction (GEJ).

  3. Absence of an Air Bubble in the Stomach: The inability of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) to relax prevents gas from entering the stomach.

24-hour pH monitoring is the least useful investigation for diagnosing Achalasia because its primary purpose is to quantify acid reflux (Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease or GERD).

  • Achalasia is a primary motility disorder characterized by LES failure to relax and loss of esophageal peristalsis. It does not primarily involve acid reflux.

  • In fact, the tight, non-relaxing LES prevents acid from refluxing, so the pH study in an untreated achalasia patient is typically normal.

  • A "pathologic" pH study in achalasia is often due to the fermentation of retained food residue, which produces lactic acid and lowers the pH, but this is a consequence of the stasis, not the primary diagnostic target.

questions.text: Which of the following are indications for radioiodine treatment? 1. Relapsed Graves’ disease 2. Thyrotoxicosis in young children 3. Multinodular goitre 4. Severe ophthalmopathy 5. Pregnancy and lactation.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Radioiodine treatment recommends the administration of enough radioiodine to achieve normalthyroid status. Hypothyroidism occurs in 15–20 per cent at 2 years. It is contraindicated in young children, pregnant and lactating mothers. It is the definitive choice of treatment in cases of relapsed Graves’ disease and in multinodular goitre and adenomas. One cause for concern is that radioactive iodine therapy has been associated with worsening Graves' ophthalmopathy. Radioiodine treatment carries a substantial risk of exacerbating pre-existing thyroid eye disease it should be avoided as far as possible in patients with active or severe ophthalmopathy.

questions.text: Identify the MRI sequence shown to you?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The key to identifying this image as Susceptibility-Weighted Imaging (SWI) is the extreme visibility of the cerebral venous architecture as numerous fine, thread-like dark (hypointense) structures extending across the cortex and deep white matter.

  • SWI Principle: SWI is a high-resolution, three-dimensional gradient-recalled echo (GRE) sequence that is highly sensitive to magnetic susceptibility differences between tissues.

  • Venous Blood: Venous blood contains deoxyhemoglobin, a paramagnetic substance that creates a local magnetic field distortion. SWI exploits this by using a long echo time (TE) and combining magnitude and phase data to enhance this susceptibility effect.

  • Appearance: This results in a marked hypointense (dark/black) signal in the veins, essentially acting as an intrinsic "black-blood" venography. This appearance is characteristic and is not seen on standard T1WI, T2WI, or FLAIR sequences.

  • Clinical Use: SWI is primarily used to detect microhemorrhages, iron deposits, and low-flow vascular malformations, as well as to visualize the detailed venous anatomy shown here.

Bazedoxifene isapproved for the treatment of moderate to severe VMS D. Ospemifene is indicated for the treatment of moderate to severe dyspareunia E. Oxandrolone is approved as an adjunct drug to increase weight gain after weight loss of surgery
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Danazol is used to treat hereditary angioedema due to deficiency of first-component esterase inhibitor letrozole has been used to treat infertility in anovulatory women Bazedoxifene isapproved for the treatment of moderate to severe VMS Ospemifene is indicated for the treatment of moderate to severe dyspareunia Oxandrolone is approved as an adjunct drug to increase weight gain after weight loss of surgery

questions.text: Which antibiotic is highly ionized in body fluids and must be given parenterally for systemic infections?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Tobramycin. Aminoglycoside antibiotics such as tobramycin are ionized in body fluids and must be given parenterally for systemic infections

questions.text: Which drug exerts a fungicidal effect by inhibiting synthesis of the fungal cell wall?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Micafungin. Micafungin, caspofungin, and anidulafungin are echinocandin drugs that inhibit the synthesis of β-(1,3)-D-glucan, a component of the fungal cell wall. Posaconazole and other azole drugs inhibit a P450 enzyme that catalyzes the formation of the lanosterol component of the fungal membrane. nystatin and amphotericin B bind to ergosterol and create pores in fungal membranes. Terbinafine inhibits squalene epoxidase and the formation of the precursor to lanosterol, squalene-2, 3-oxide

questions.text: Match the following regarding drug and its target
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Alemtuzumab- binds to CD52 Ipilimumab- cytotoxic T-lymphocyte–associated antigen 4 Cetuximab- epidermal growth factor Nivolumab- programmed death-1 (PD-1)
